con.para: Friction is a force that happens when two surfaces rub against each other. It slows things down or makes them stop.
There are different types of friction: sliding (when things slide past each other), rolling (wheels on a road), and static (when an object is still).
Friction helps us do things like walk without slipping, write with a pencil, and drive safely. Without friction, we’d slip and slide everywhere!
Rubbing your hands together makes them warm because friction turns movement into heat. The more friction there is, the hotter things get!
Sometimes we need to reduce friction. Things like oil or wheels help objects move smoothly without slowing down.
Air resistance is a type of friction that happens when something moves through the air. It pushes against the object, slowing it down.
Things like parachutes, falling leaves, and paper planes are all affected by air resistance, which slows them down.
Streamlining means shaping things so that air moves around them easily. This reduces air resistance and helps them go faster!

con.title: Friction and Air Resistance in Sports

con.para: Sports like skiing, cycling, and swimming use special gear and body positions to reduce friction and air resistance, helping athletes move faster.
